characters: EXT. N.Y. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS

dialogues.speaker: EXT. N.Y. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS
dialogues.text: A large, imposing building, gray, impressive as a backgro the comings and goings of a number of ordinary people on ordinary day. Camera holds on steps and building front fr distance and then dollies in slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seething with activity, people of all kinds walking swift purposefully to and from elevators, newsstands, etc. Othe standing, waiting. Guards stationed at various posts. Cam across lobby and then dollies into a bank of elevators. A of people crowd into one. The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevators on left. Many doorways to various courtroom right. Each door marked with a hanging sign. The first si “Court of General Sessions. Part I”. The second sign read of General Sessions. Part II” etc. An elevator door opens number of people exit and walk down the corridor. Other p men and women, stand in the corridor talking. The whole f one of movement, activity, intense concentration. Everyon purpose. -Camera dollies down the corridor, following a g people who exited from the elevator. People peel off from group at various doors. At each door stands a guard. Peop in and out of the doors. Camera reaches the door marked “ and pans around to face the door. A guard stands in front impassively. No one else is in front of the door, as comp the knots of whispering people in front of all the other The case going on in “Part VI” obviously has very little interest. ‘Through the glass window of the door we can se the background, the judge at his bench. He is facing to h and talking. We hear nothing. He stops and turns to his r He raises his hand as if calling the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Sn at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty water From the noise stillness of a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: glass on a tray. of the corridor we are now in the deathlike courtroom. A hand places a freshly-filled pitcher of water on the tray. A pair of hands fills a glass from pitcher. Camera pans with glass as it is raised. Camera h close-up of judge, drinking the water. He finishes, puts down, and turns to his left again. He clears his throat. begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young Puerto

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: ..-and that concludes the court's explanation of the legal aspects of this case. And now, gentlemen of the jury, I come to my final instruction to you. Murder in the first degree - - premeditated homicide -- is the most serious charge tried in our criminal courts. You've listened to the testimony and you've had the law read to you and interpreted as it applies to this case. It now becomes your duty to try and separate the facts from the fancy. One man is dead. The life of another is at stake. I urge you to deliberate honestly and thoughtfully. If there is a reasonable doubt -- then you must bring me a verdict of "not guilty". If, however, there is no reasonable doubt, then you must, in good conscience, find the accused guilty. However you decide, your verdict must be unanimous. In the event you find the accused guilty...

dialogues.speaker: ACCUSED
dialogues.text: Rican man vulnerable and afraid.

dialogues.speaker: _. JUDGE, (CONT)
dialogues.text: ...the bench will not entertain a recommendation for mercy. The death sentence is mandatory in this case. I don't envy you your job. You are faced with a grave responsibility. Thank you, gentlemen. There is a brief pause. The jurors file out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very hot summer afternoon. It is a large, drab, bare ro need of painting, with three windows in the back wall thr can be seen the New York skyline. Off the jury room is a with a lavatory beyond. A large, scarred table is C with chairs around it. A bench stands against the wall and the several extra chairs and a small table in the room, plus cooler, with paper cups and a waste basket and an electri the bench and a clock over the cooler and row of hooks fo with a shelf over it. There are pencils, pads and ashtray table. At night the room is lit by fluorescent lighting w switch next to the door. The Jurors enter preceded by a Guard. He checks his list. Juror, an old man, crosses, goes into the washroom, and e the lavatory. The 4th Juror begins to read a newspaper. S jurors open the windows. Others move awkwardly about the There is no conversation for a few moments. The 3rd Juror out some notes and studies them. The 2nd Juror crosses to water-cooler, gets a cup of water. The Foreman tears a sh the notepad and tears up little slips of paper for ballot Guard crosses to the 12th Juror and checks his name. The crosses to the 4th Juror and offers him a stick of gum. T Juror shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (turning to the 8th Juror) Do you want some gum?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (smiling) No thanks. The 7th Juror vigorously chews a piece of gum himself and to the 6th Juror.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (mopping his brow) y'know something? I phoned up for the weather. This is the hottest day of the year.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (the 6th Juror nods and gazes out the window) You'd think they'd at least air condition the place. I almost dropped dead in court.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Okay, gentlemen. Everybody's here. If there's anything you want, I'm right outside. Just knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard exits and in the silence the sound is heard of being locked.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I never knew they locked the door.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure they lock the door. What'd you think?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know. It just never occurred to me. The 10th Juror crosses and pauses beside the Foreman and the. slips of paper.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Hey, what's that for?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Well, I figured we might want to vote by ballots.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Great idea! Maybe we can get him elected senator. He laughs until he begins to cough. The Foreman looks at his watch and compares it with the c 3rd Juror takes a cup of water from the water-cooler, mov 2nd Juror and looks around the room as he sips the water.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 2nd Juror) How'd you like it?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: . (mildly) I don't know, it was pretty interesting.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah? I was falling asleep.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: I mean, I've never been on a jury before.  oe —

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Really? I've sat on juries, and it always amazes me the way these lawyers can talk, and talk and talk, even when the case is as obvious as this one. I mean, did you ever hear so much talk about nothing?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I guess they're entitled.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure they are. Everybody deserves a fair trial. That's the system. Listen, I'm the last one to say anything against it, but I'm telling you sometimes I think we'd be better off if we took these tough kids. and slapped 'em down before they make trouble, you know? Save us a lot of time and money. The 2nd Juror looks nervously at the 3rd Juror, nods, ris to the water-cooler, refills his cup and stands alone, si

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the Foreman) Hey, how about getting started here?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's get this over with. We've probably all got things todo.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Well, I was figuring we'd take a five-minute break. I mean, one man's in the bathroom...

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the Foreman, hesitantly) Are we going to sit in order? FOREMAN . What? I don't know. I suppose so. The 8th Juror is looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) Not a bad view. (the 8th Juror nods) What d'you think of the case?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (the 8th Juror doesn't answer) It had a-lot of interest for me. No dead spots -- know what I mean? I['11 tell you we were lucky to get a murder case. I figured us for a burglary or an assault or something. Those can be the dullest. (he looks out of the window) Say, isn't that the Woolworth Building?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Funny, I've lived here all my life and I've never been in it. The 8th Juror gazes ‘out of the window. The 12th Juror lo for a moment then moves away. The 7th Juror, talking with Juror, laughs)

dialogues.speaker: . 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, can you imagine, sitting there for three days just for this?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: And what about that business with the knife? I mean, asking grown-up people to believe that kind of bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, look, you've gotta expect that. You know what you're dealing with.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, I suppose so. . (the 10th Juror blows his nose vigorously) What's the matter, you got a cold?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: And how. These hot weather colds can kill you. I can hardly touch my nose. Know what I mean? (he blows his nose loudly)  Yr

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, your horn's all right. Now try your lights. (the 7th Juror climbs on to the bench and tries the fan) Oh, that's beautiful, the fan doesn't work. (he steps down) Somebody take a letter to.the mayor. "Dear Stingy..." The 3rd Juror moves about the 4th Juror, leans over and s 4th Juror's newspaper. The Foreman climbs on the bench an examines the fan)

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 4th Juror) I didn't get a chance to look at the newspapers today. Anything new going on?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I was just wondering how the market closed.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know. Say, are you on the Exchange or something?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm a broker.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Really? I run a messenger service. "The Beck and Call Company." The name's by wife's idea. I employ thirty-seven people... started with nothing...

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking at his watch) Hey, Mr. Foreman, let's go. What d'you say?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen. Let's take seats.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 2nd Juror) This better be fast. I got tickets to a ball game tonight. Yankees -- Cleveland. We got this new kid pitching, Modjelewski, or whatever his name is. He's a bull, this kid. (He shoots his hand forward and out to indicate the path of a curve ball) Shhooooooom. A real jug handle. (no reaction at all from the 2nd Juror) You're quite a ball fan, aren't you? (He turns to the Foreman) Where do you want us to sit?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Well, I was thinking we ought to sit in order, by jury numbers. (he points with each number) Two, three, four, and so on, if that's okay with you gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH. JUROR
dialogues.text: What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think it's reasonable to sit according to number.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (rising) Let it be. He moves and sits on chair 10. The Jurors begin to take their seats. The 8th Juror conti star out of the window. The 9th Juror is still in the lav

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 11th Juror) What was your impression of the prosecuting attorney?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (with a German accent) I beg pardon?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I thought he was really sharp. I mean, the way he hammered home his points, one by one, in logical sequence.  wy = wT oS =a

dialogues.speaker: JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: It takes a good brain to do that. I was very impressed.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yes, I think he did an expert job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, he had a lot of drive, too. Real drive.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay, let's get this show on the road.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) How about sitting down? (the 8th Juror does not hear the Foreman) The gentleman at the window. (The 8th Juror turns, startled) How about sitting down?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. He moves his chair and sits. The 9th Juror enters the washroom from the lavatory and w hands.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (across the table to the 4th Juror) It's pretty tough to figure, isn't it? A kid kills his father. Bing! Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, if you analyze the figures...

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What figures, it’s those people. I'm tellin' you they let the kids run wild up there. Well, maybe it serves ‘em right. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Is everybody here?  —Vv ow “oy

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (with a gesture towards the washroom) The old man's inside.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Would you knock on the door? The 6th Juror rises and moves to the washroom door.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 5th Juror) Hey, you a Yankee fan?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. Milwaukee.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Milwaukee! That's like being hit on the head with a crowbar once a day. Listen, who they got... (the 6th Juror knocks on the washroom door) ...I'm asking you, who they got besides great grounds-keepers? The 9th Juror enters from the washroom.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (to the 7th Juror) We'd like to get started

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (he crosses to his seat)

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Milwaukee!

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to keep you waiting.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: All right. Now you gentlemen can handle this any way you want to. I mean, I'm not going to have any rules. If we want to discuss it first and then vote, that's one way. Or we can vote right now to see how we stand. (he pauses and looks around) Well, that's all I have to say.  slowly.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think it's customary to take a preliminary vote.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's vote. Who knows, maybe we can all go home.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: It's up to you. Just let's remember we've got a first degree murder charge here. If we vote "guilty" we send the accused to the electric chair. That's mandatory.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think we all know that.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on, let's vote.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's see who's where.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Anybody doesn't want to vote? (he looks around, the others are silent) All right. This has to be a twelve- to-nothing vote either way. That's the law. Okay, are we ready? All those voting "guilty" raise your hands. Seven or eight hands go up immediately. Several others go Everyone looks around the table as the Foreman rises and begins to count hands. The 9th Juror's hand goes up now, hands are raised except the 8th Juror's.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: ...Nine -- ten -- eleven. That's eleven for "guilty". Okay, "Not guilty." The 8th Juror slowly raises his hand. He resumes his seat.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: One. Right. Okay, eleven to one -- "Guilty". Now we know where we are.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Boy-oh-boy! There's always one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S=S — aT — — a

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (after a pause) So what do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I guess we talk.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Boy-oh-boy!

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (leaning over towards the 8th juror) Well, look, do you really think he's innocent?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I mean, let's be reasonable. You sat in court and heard the same things we did. The man's a dangerous killer. You could see it.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The man! He's sixteen years old. ‘ 3RD JUROR Well, that's old enough. He knifed his own father. Four inches into the chest.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) It's pretty obvious. I mean, I was convinced from the first day.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, who wasn't? (to the 8th Juror) I really think this is one of those open and shut things. They proved it a dozen different ways. Would you like me to list them for you?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Then what. do you want?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just want to talk.

dialogues.speaker: . 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what's there to talk about? Eleven men here agree. Nobody had to think twice about it, except you.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I want to ask you something. Do you believe his story?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know whether I believe it or not. Maybe I don't.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: So what'd you vote "not guilty" for?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: There were eleven votes for “guilty.” It's not easy for me to raise my hand and send a°boy off to die without talking about it first.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Who says it's.easy for me?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No-one.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What, just because I voted fast? I think the guy's guilty. You couldn't change my mind if you talked for a hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to change your mind. It's just that we're talking about somebody's life here. I mean, we can't decide in five minutes. Suppose we're wrong?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Suppose we're wrong! Suppose this whole building fell on my head. You can suppose anything.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (after a pause) What's the difference how long it takes? We honestly think he's guilty. So suppose we finish in five minutes? So what?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Let's take an hour. The ball game doesn't start till eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (smiling) Okay, slugger, be my guest. There is a silence.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Well, who's got something to say? He looks at the 2nd Juror.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm willing to put in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Great. I heard a pretty good story last night. This woman comes running into the doctor's office, stripped to the waist...

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's not what we're sitting here for.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right, then you tell me. What are we sitting here for?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe for no reason. I don't know. Look, this boy's been kicked around all his life. You know -- living in a slum, his mother dead since he was nine. He spent a year and a half in an orphanage while his father served a jail term for forgery. That's not a very good head start. He's had a pretty terrible sixteen years.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I think maybe we owe him a few words. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't mind telling you this, mister. We don't owe him a thing. He got a fair trial, didn't he? What d'you think the trial cost? He's lucky he got it. Know what I mean? (he rises and looks around at the others) Look, we're all grown-ups here. We heard the facts, didn't we? Now you're not going to tell us that we're supposed to believe that kid, knowing what he is. Listen, I've lived among 'em all my life. You can't believe a word they say. You know that. I mean, they're born liars.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It suddenly occurs to me that you must be an ignorant man.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What do you mean? What's he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Do you think you have a monopoly on the truth?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What are you making a Federal Case out of it for? (to the others) How d’ya like this guy?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the others) I think certain things should be pointed out to this man.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. It's not Sunday. We don't need a sermon in here.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Monopoly! For Chrissakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 9th Juror half rises but then feels the 8th Juror's h on his arm, gently pulling him down. The 12th Juror doodl notepad. : .

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't see any need for arguing like this. I think we ought to be able to behave like gentlemen. If we're going to discuss this case, let's stick to the facts.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I think that's a good point. We have a job to do. Let's do it. Maybe if the gentleman who's disagreeing down there could tell us why. You know, tell -us what he thinks -- we could show him where he's probably mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking at the.12th Juror's doodle) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Mmm? (he holds up the doodle) It's one of the products I work on at the AD Agency. Rice Pops. "The Breakfast with the Built-In Bounce." I wrote that line.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (smiling in spite of himself) It's very catchy.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: If you don't mind! The 2nd Juror rises, goes to the coat-hooks and takes a p cough drops from his jacket pocket)

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I have this habit of doodling. It keeps me thinking clearly.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: We're trying to get some place here. Y'know we can sit here forever...

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, look, maybe this is an idea. I'm just thinking out loud, but it seems to me it's up to us to convince this gentleman -- (he indicates the 8th Juror) that we're right and he's wrong. Maybe if we each took a minute or two. I mean it's just a quick thought...

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: No, I think it's a good one. Supposing we go once around the table. :

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Anything. Let's start it off.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. . (to the 7th Juror) How about you going first?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Not me. I think we oughta go in order.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: That sounds fair. Okay, in order -- a coupla minutes apiece. (To the 2nd Juror) I guess you're first.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Oh. Well -- (he pauses nervously) Well, it's hard to put into words. I just -- think he's guilty. I thought it was obvious from the word go. I mean nobody proved otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Nobody has to prove otherwise. The burden of proof is on the prosecution. The defendant doesn't have to open his mouth. That's in the Constitution. You've heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: (flustered) Well, sure I've heard of it. I know what it is. I -- what I meant -- well, the man is guilty. I mean, somebody saw him do it. He looks around helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay. (he refers to his notes) Now here's what I think, and I have no personal feelings about this. I'm talking facts. Number one. Let's take the old man who lived on the second floor right underneath the room where the murder took place. At ten minutes after twelve on the night of the killing he heard loud noises in the apartment upstairs. He said it sounded like a fight. Then he heard the kid shout out, "I'm gonna kill you." A. second later he heard a body fall and he ran to the door of his apartment, looked out and saw the kid running down the stairs and out of the house. Then he called the police. They found the father with a knife in his chest.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: And the coroner fixed the time of the death at around midnight.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Right. I mean, there are facts for you. You can't refute facts. This boy is guilty. Look, I'm as sentimental as the next guy. I know the kid is only sixteen, but he's still got to pay for what he did.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm with you, pops.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (removing his eyeglasses) It was obvious to me, anyway, that the boy's entire story was flimsy. He claimed he was at the movies during the time of the killing and yet one hour later he couldn't  ge a

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: remember what films he saw or who played in them.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right. Did you hear that? (to the 4th Juror) You're absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: . _ 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No-one saw him going into or out of the theater.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, what about that woman across the street? If her testimony don't prove it, nothing does. :

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right. She was the one who actually saw the killing.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (half rising) Let's go in order here.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (rising, handkerchief in hand) Just a minute. Here's a woman... (he blows his nose) Here's a woman who's lying in bed and can't sleep. She's dying with the heat. Know what I mean? . Anyway, she looks out the window and right across the street she sees the kid stick the knife into his father. The time is twelve-ten on.the nose. Everything fits. Look, she's known the kid all his life. His window is right opposite hers, across the el tracks, and she swore she saw him do it.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Through the windows of a passing elevated train.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Right. This el train had no passengers on it. It was just being moved downtown. The lights were out, remember? And they proved in court that at night you can look through the windows of an el train when the lights are out and see what's

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: happening on the other side. They proved it.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 10th Juror) I'd like to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You don't believe the boy. How come you believe the woman? She's one of "them", too, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (suddenly angry) You're a pretty smart fellow, aren't -you? He crosses towards the 8th Juror. Several Jurors rise as ' intercept the 10th Juror. The 10th Juror

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Hey, let's take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JURY
dialogues.text: (angrily) What's he so wise about? I'm telling you...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on. Sit down. What are you letting him get you all upset for? sits.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Let's calm down now. Let's try to keep it peaceful in here. Whose turn is it?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (indicating the 5th Juror) His.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. (to the 5th Juror) You've got two minutes.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking nervously around) I'll pass it.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: That's your privilege. How about the next gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know. I started to be convinced, uh -- you know, very early in the case.. Well, I was looking for the motive. That's very important. If there's no motive, where's the case? So, anyway, that testimony from those people across the hall from the kid's apartment, that was very powerful. Didn't they say something about an argument between the father and the boy around seven o'clock that night? I mean, I can be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was eight o'clock. Not seven.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right. Eight o'clock. They heard an argument, but they couldn't hear. what it was about. Then they heard the father hit the boy twice, and finally they saw the boy walk angrily out of the house. What does that prove?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, it doesn't exactly prove anything. It's just part of the picture. I didn't say it proved anything.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You said it revealed a motive for the killing. The prosecuting attorney said the same thing. Well, I don't think it's a very strong motive. This boy has been hit so many times in his life that violence is practically a normal state of affairs for him. I can't see two slaps in the face provoking him into committing murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nv nv

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (quietly) : It may have been two slaps too many. Everyone has a breaking point.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (to the 6th juror) Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (to the 7th Juror) How about the next gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Me? . (he pauses, looks around, shrugs) I don’t know, it’s practically all said already. We can talk about it forever. I mean, this kid is oh for five. Look at his record. He was in Chidren’s Court when he was ten for throwing a rock at his teacher. At fourteen he was in Reform School. He stole a car. He’s been arrested for mugging. He was picked up twice for tyring to slash another teenager with a knife. He’s real quick with switch knives, they said. This is a very fine boy.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Ever since he was five years old his father beat him up regularly. He used his fists.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: So would I. A kid like that.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Wouldn't you call those beatings a motive for him to kill his father?  a ST

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRAFT
dialogues.text: He breaks off. embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I don't know. It's a motive for him to be an angry kid. I'11 say that.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: It's the kids, the way they are mowadays. Angry! Hostile! You can't do a damn thing with them. Just. the way they talk to you. Listen, when I was his age I used to call my father. "Sir". That’s right. Sir! You ever hear a boy call his father that any more?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Fathers don't seem to think it's important any more.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: No? Have you got any kids?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I've got one. He's twenty. We did everything for that boy and what happened? When he was nine he ran away from a fight. I saw him. I was so ashamed I almost threw up. So I told him right out. "I'm gonna make a man outta you or I'm gonna bust you in half trying." Well, I made a man outta him all - right. When he was sixteen we had a battle. He hit me in the face. He's big, y'know. I haven't seen him in two years. Rotten kid. You work your heart out... He has said more than he intended. He is

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Let's get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (rising) I think we're missing the point here. This boy, let's say he's a product of a filthy neighborhood and a broken home. We can't help that.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: We're here to decide whether he's guilty or‘“innocent of murder, not to go into reasons why he grew up this way: He was born in a slum. Slums are breeding grounds for criminals. I know it. So-do you. It's no secret: Children from slum backgrounds are potential menaces to society. Now I think...

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Brother, you can say that again. The kids who crawl outta those places are real trash. I don't want any part of them. I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (rising) I've lived in a slum all my life... I nurse that trash in Harlem Hospital six nights a week.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Oh, now wait a second...

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I used to play in a back yard that was filled with garbage. Maybe it still smells on me.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (his anger rising) Now listen, sonny...

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (to the 5th Juror) Now let's be reasonable. There's nothing personal...

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (loudly) There is something personal! The 3rd Juror moves to the 5th Juror and pats him on the The 5th Juror does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on, now. He didn't mean you, feller. Let's not be so sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: This sensitivity I understand.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: All right: let's stop all this arguing. We're wasting time here. (he points to the 8th Juror) It's your turn. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't expect a turn. I thought you were all supposed to be convincing me. Wasn't that the idea?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Check. I forgot about that.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what’s the difference? He's the one who’s keeping us here. Let’s hear what he’s got to say.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Now just a second. We decided to do it a certain way. lLet’s stick to what we said.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (disgusted) Ah, stop bein’ a kid, will you?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: A kid! Listen, what d’you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What d’ya think I mean? K-I-D, kid! FOREMAN . What, just because I’m trying to keep this thing organized? Listen. (he rises) You want to do it? Here. You sit here. You take the responsibility. I’ll just shut up, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, what are you gettin’ so hot about? Calm down, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Don't tell me to calm down. Here! Here's the chair. You keep it goin' smooth and everything. What d'ya think, it's a snap'? Come on, Mr. Foreman. Let's see how great you'd run the show.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 11th Juror) - Did y'ever see such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: You think it's funny or something?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Take it easy. The whole thing's unimportant.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Unimportant? You want to try it?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. Listen, you're doing a beautiful job. Nobody wants to change.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're doing great. Hang in there and pitch.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Let's hear from somebody. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, if you want me to tell you how I feel about it right now, it's all right with me.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: (softly) I don't care what you do.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (after a pause) All right. I haven't got anything brilliant. I only know as much as you do. According to the testimony the boy looks guilty. Maybe he is. I sat there in court for three days listening while the evidence built

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: up. Everybody sounded so positive that I started to get a peculiar feeling about this trial. I mean, nothing is that positive. I had questions I would have liked to ask. Maybe they wouldn't have meant anything. I don't know. But I started to feel that the defense counsel wasn't doing his job. He let too many things go. Little things.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What little things? Listen, when these guys don't ask questions, that's because they know the answers already and they figure they'll be hurt.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe. It's also possible for a lawyer to be just plain stupid, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You sound like you've met my brother-in-law. A few jurors laugh.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (smiling) : I kept putting myself in the boy's place. I would have asked for another lawyer, I think. I mean, if I was on trial for my life I'd want my lawyer to tear the prosecution witnesses to shreds, or at least to try. Look, there was one alleged eye-witness to this killing. Someone else claims he heard the killing and then saw the boy running out afterwards. There was a lot of circumstantial evidence, but actually those two witnesses were the entire case for the prosecution. Supposing they were wrong?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What do you mean, "Supposing they were wrong?" What's the point of having witnesses at all?"

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Could they be wrong?

dialogues.speaker: / 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: They sat on the stand under oath. What are you trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: They're only people. People make mistakes. Could they be wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: I... No! I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Do you know so?

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, now, listen. Nobody can know a thing like that. This isn't an exact science. .

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right. It isn't.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (rising angrily) All right. - (to the 8th Juror) Let's try to get to the point here. What about the switch-knife they found in the father's chest?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, wait a minute. I think we oughta... There are some people who haven't talked yet. Shouldn't we...?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Look, they can talk whenever they like. Now just be quiet a second, will you. (he turns to the 8th Juror) Okay, what about the knife? You know, the one that fine, upright boy admitted buying on the night of the murder. Let's talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right, let's talk about it. Let's get it in here and look at it. I'd like to see it again. (He turns to the Foreman) Mr. Foreman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Foreman rises and crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: We all know what it looks like. The Foreman knocks on the door. The Guard enters. The For whispers to him. The Guard nods and exits.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What are we gonna get out of seeing it again?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You brought it up.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The gentleman has a right to see exhibits in evidence. (to the 8th Juror) The knife, and the way it was bought, is pretty strong evidence. Don't you think so?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Good. Now suppose we take these facts one at a time. One. The boy admitted going out of his house at eight o’clock on the night of the murder after being punched several times by his father.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He didn't say "punched". He said "hit". There's a difference between a slap and a punch.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: After being hit several times by his father, Two. The boy went directly to a neighborhood junk shop where he bought a... What do you call these things --

dialogues.speaker: ' 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Switch-knives.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR/4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: --a switchblade knife.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 3rd Juror) Thank you: Three. This wasn't what you'd call an ordinary knife. It had a very unusual carved handle. Four. The storekeeper who sold it to him identified the knife in court and said it was the only one of its kind he had ever had in stock. Five. At, oh, about eight-forty-five the boy ran into three friends of his in front of a diner. Am I correct so far?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yes, you are.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) You bet he is. (to the others) Now listen to this man. He knows what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR -
dialogues.text: The boy talked with his friends for about an hour, leaving them at nine- forty-five. During this time they saw the switch-knife. Six. Each of them identified the death weapon in court as that same knife. Seven. The boy arrived home at about ten o'clock. Now this is where the stories offered by the boy and the State begin to diverge slightly. He claims that he stayed home until eleven-thirty and then went to one of those all-night movies. He returned home at about three-fifteen in the morning to find his father dead and himself arrested. Now, what happened to the switch-knife? This is the charming and imaginative little fable the boy invented. He claims that the knife fell through a hole in his pocket some time between eleven- thirty and three-fifteen while he was on his trip to the movies and that he never saw it again. Now this is a tale, gentlemen. I think it's quite clear that the boy never went to the movies that night.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: No one in the house saw-him go out at eleven-thirty. No one at the theater identified him. He couldn't even remember the names of the pictures he saw. What actually happened is this: the boy stayed home, had. another fight with his father, stabbed him to death with the knife at ten minutes after twelve and fled from the house. He even remembered to wipe the knife clean of fingerprints. The Guard enters carrying a curiously designed knife with hanging from-it. The 4th Juror goes to the Guard, takes t from him. The guard exits.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Everyone connected with the case identified the knife. Now are you trying to tell me that it really fell through a hole in the boy's pocket and that someone picked it up off the ‘street, went to the boy's house and stabbed his father with it just to be amusing?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. I'm saying it's possible that the boy lost the knife and that someone else stabbed his father with a similar knife. It's possible. The 4th Juror flicks open the knife and jams it into the

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Take a look at that knife. I've never seen one like it. Neither had the storekeeper who sold it to the boy. Aren't you asking us to accept a pretty incredible coincidence?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm not asking anyone to accept it. I'm just saying that it's possible.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (shouting) And I'm saying it's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 8th Juror stands for a moment in silence, then he rea his pocket and swiftly withdraws a knife. He olds it in f his face and flicks open the blade, then he leans forward sticks the knife into the table alongside the other. They exactly alike. There is a burst of sound in the room. The Juror stands back from the table, watching.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Look at it! It's the same knife.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Where'd that come from?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: How d'you like that?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD. JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking at the 8th Juror, amazed) What are you trying to do?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah. What's going on here? Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Quiet! Let's be quiet. (to the 8th Juror) Were d'you get that knife? 8TH JUROR . I was walking for a couple of hours last night, just thinking. I walked through the boy's neighborhood. The knife comes from a little pawnshop three blocks from his house. It cost six dollars.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It's against the law to buy or sell switch-blade knives.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right. I broke the law.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen. You pulled a real bright trick here. Now supposing you tell me what you proved? Maybe there are ten knives like that. So what?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe there are.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: So what does that mean? It's the same kind of knife. So what's that? The discovery of the age or something?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It would still be an incredible coincidence for another person to have stabbed the father with the same kind of knife.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right! He's right.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The odds are a million to one.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: But not very probable.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Listen, let's take seats. There's no point in milling around here. They begin to move back to their seats. The 8th Juror sta watching.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: It's interesting that he'd find a knife exactly like the one the boy bought.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What's interesting? You think it proves anything?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, no. I was just...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Interesting! (he points at the 8th Juror) Listen, how come the kid bought the knife to begin with?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, he claims that...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I know. He claims he bought it as a present for a friend of his. He was gonna give it to him the next day because he busted the other kid’s knife dropping it on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Baloney!

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The friend testified that the boy did break his knife.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah. And how long before the killing? Three weeks. Right? So how come our noble lad bought this knife one half hour after his father smacked him and three and a half hours before they found it shoved up to here in the father's chest?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, he was gonna give the knife to his friend. He just wanted to use it for a minute. There is scattered laughter.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 3rd Juror) Let me ask you this. It's one of the questions I wanted to ask in court. If the boy bought the knife to use on his father, how come he showed what was going to be the murder weapon to three friends of his just a couple of hours before the killing?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, all of this is just talk. The boy lied and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He may have lied. (to 10th Juror) Do you think he lied?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now that's a stupid question. Sure he lied.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 4th Juror) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You don't have to ask me that. You know my answer. He lied.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 5th Juror) Do you think he lied?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think maybe he... He breaks off and looks nervously around.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (leaping into the breach) Maybe! Now wait a second. (to 8th Juror) What are you, the kid's lawyer or something? Who do you think you are to start cross-examining us?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Isn't that what's supposed to happen in a jury room?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, there are still eleven of us in here who think he's guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah. What do you think you're gonna accomplish? You're not gonna change anybody's mind. So if you want to be stubborn and hang this jury, go ahead. The kid’s be tried again and found guilty sure as he's born.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR -
dialogues.text: So what are you gonna do about it? We can be here all night.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It's only one night. A boy may die.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Brother. Anybody got a deck of cards? ~

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the Foreman) I don't think he ought to make a joke about it.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't see what all this stuff about the knife has to do with anything. Somebody saw the kids stab his father. What more do we need? I got three garages of mind going to pot while you're talking. Let's get done and get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The knife was very important to the district attorney. He spent one whole morning...

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He's a fifteenth assistant or something. What does he know?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. I think we oughta get on with it now. These side arguments only slow us up. (to the 8th Juror) What about it?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) You're the only one.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I have a proposition to make to all of you. I want to call for a vote. I'd like you eleven men to vote by secret written ballot. I'll abstain. If there are still eleven votes for guilty, I won't stand alone. We'll take a guilty verdict in to the judge right now. But if anyone votes not guilty, we'll stay and talk this thing out.  ne

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (he pauses) Well, that's all. I£ you want to try it, I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, finally you're behaving like a reasonable man.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Check. I'11 buy that.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's do it.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: That sounds fair. Some of the Jurors nod. The 8th Juror moves to the window

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Anyone doesn't agree? Okay. Pass these along. He passes out the slips of paper. The 8th Juror stands watching the others. The Jurors pass slips along. Finally each of them begins to write. Now so them begin to fold their slips and pass them back to the The Foreman stacks all the slips on the table in front of picks up the first slip of paper, opens it and reads:

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Guilty. (he opens and reads the other slips in turn) Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Guilty. Not. Guilty. There is a babble of voices. The 8th Juror relaxes, moves chair and sits. Foreman reads the last slip.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Boy! How do you like that?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: } And another chap flips his goddam wig!

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right, who was it? Come on. I want to khow.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Excuse me. This was a secret ballot. We agreed on this. .

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Secret? What d'ya mean, secret? There are no secrets in a jury room. I know who it was. (he. crosses to the 5th Juror) Brother, you're really something! You come in here and you vote guilty like everybody else, and then this golden-voiced preacher over here starts to tear your heart out with stories about a poor little kid who just couldn't help becoming a murderer. So you change your vote. If that isn't the most sickening... Why don'tcha drop a quarter in his . collection box?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. (the 3rd juror turns away) You can’t talk to me like that! The 3rd Juror turns to face him. The 4th Juror slips in b them and takes the 5th Juror by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. (he shakes off the 4th Juror). Where does he get the right to shout at me?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Let's calm down.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Who does he think he is? I mean, did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Just sit down. He's very excitable. Forget it. It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You bet I!m excitable. We're trying to put a guilty man into the chair where he belongs and all of a sudden somebody's telling us fairy tales -- and we're listening.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: (mildly) Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What do you mean -- take it easy! D'you feel like seeing a proven murderer walking the streets? Why don't we give him his knife back? Make it easier for him.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, let's stop the yelling. Who's got something constructive to say?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Please. I would like to say something here. I have always thought that in this country a man was entitled to have unpopular opinions... ,

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Let's stick to the subject. (to the 5th Juror) What made you change your vote?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He didn't change his vote. I did. Would you like me to tell you why?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't like you to tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well I'd like to make it clear, anyway, if you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Do we have to listen to this?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Hey look! The man wants to talk.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to the 7th Juror) This gentleman -- (he indicates the 8th Juror) has been standing alone against us. He doesn't say the boy is not guilty. He just isn't sure. Well, it's not easy to stand alone against the ridicule of others. He gambled for support and I gave it to him. I respect his motives. The boy on trial is probably guilty. But I want to hear more. (The 7th Juror crosses to the washroom) For the time being the vote is ten to two. . (the 7th Juror enters the washroom, slams the door after him) : I'm talking here. You have no right to...

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 9th Juror) He can't hear you. He never will. Let's sit down.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, if the speech is over, maybe we can go on.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I think we ought to take a break. One man's inside there. Let's wait for him. The Foreman moves above the table.to where the two knives into it. He plucks the tagged knife out and closes it.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 11th Juror) Looks like we're really hung up here. I mean, that thing with the old man was pretty unexpected. I wish I knew how we could break this up. (he suddenly smiles) Y'know, in advertising... I told you I worked at an ad agency, didn't I? The Foreman crosses to the door and knocks. The Guard ent Foreman hands him the knife. The Guard exits.  FIRST DRAFT - 2/14/96 a

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, there are some pretty strange people -- not strange, really -- they just have peculiar ways of expressing themselves, y'know what I mean? (the 11th Juror nods) Well, it’s probably the same in your business -- right? What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm a watchmaker.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Really? The finest watchmakers come from Europe, I imagine. The llth Juror bows slightly. The 6th Juror rises, goes i bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: Anyway, I was telling you -- in the agency, when they reach a point like this in a meeting, there's always ‘some character ready with an idea. And it kills me, I mean it's the weirdest thing sometimes the way they precede the idea with some kind of phrase. Like -- oh, some account exec'll say, "Here's an idea. Let's run it up the flagpole and see if anyone salutes it," or "Put it ona bus and see if it gets off at Wall Street." I mean, it's idiotic, but it's funny. 8th Juror goes into the washroom and hangs his jacket on 3rd Juror crosses to 5th Juror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to 5th Juror) Look, I was a little excited. Well, you know how it is -- I didn't mean to get nasty or anything. 5th Juror crosses away from 3rd Juror without answering. steps away from the washbasin and dries his hands. The 8t crosses to washbasin.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 8th Juror) Say, are you a salesman?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm an architect.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You know what the soft sell is? You're pretty good at it. I'll tell ya. I got a different technique. Jokes. Drinks. Knock 'em on their asses. I made twenty-seven thousand last year selling marmalade. That's not bad. Considering marmalade. (he watches the 8th Juror for a moment ) What are ya getting out of it -- kicks? The boy is guilty, pal. So let's go home before we get sore throats.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What's the difference whether you get one here or at the ball game?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No difference pal... No difference at all. 7th Juror exits the washroom. 6th Juror enters from the l goes to the washbasin and washes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) Nice bunch of guys.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I guess they're the same as any.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That loud, heavy-set guy, the one who was tellin' us about his kid -- the way he was talking -- boy, that was an embarrassing thing.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What a murderous day. You think we'll be here much longer?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He's guilty for sure. There's not a doubt in the whole world. We shoulda been done already. Listen, I don't care, y'know. It beats workin’.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (8th Juror smiles) You think he's innocent?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know you, but I'm bettin' you've never been wronger in your. life. Y'oughta wrap it up. You're wastin' your time.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Suppose you were the one on trial?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm not used to supposing. I'm just a working man. My boss does the supposing. But I'll try one. Suppose you talk us all outta this and the kid really did knife his father? The 6th Juror looks at the 8th Juror for a moment. then g Do the jury room. The 8th Juror stands alone for a few mo know that this is the problem which has been tormenting h does not know, and never will. He switches out the washro goes into the jury room.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, let's take seats.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Looks like we'll be here for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's get down to business. - Who wants to start it off? There is a pause, then the 4th and 6th Jurors start to sp same time.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR/4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like to make a point...

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 4th Juror) Pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: ' 4TH JUROR/6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe it would be profitable if we...

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (t6 the 6th juror) I'm sorry, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. Go ahead. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I was going to say, well, this is probably a small point, but anyway... (to the 8th Juror) The boy had a motive for the killing. You know, the beatings and all. So if he didn't do it, who did? Who else had the motive? That's my point. JI mean, nobody goes out and kills someone without a motive, not unless he's just plain nuts. Right?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: As far as I know we're supposed to decide whether or not the boy on trial is guilty beyond a reasonable - doubt. We're not concerned with anyone else's motives here. That's a job for the police.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Very true. But we can't help letting the only motive we know of creep into our thoughts, can we? And we can't help asking ourselves who else might have had a motive. Logically, these things follow. (he nods towards the 6th juror) This gentleman is asking a reasonable question.. Somebody killed him. If it wasn't the boy, who was it?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Modjelewski.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You're talking about the man I love!

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: If you haven't got anything to add besides jokes, I suggest you listen.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay. It's just letting off steam. I'm sorry. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) Well, maybe you can answer me. Who else might have killed the father?

dialogues.speaker: _ 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. The father wasn't exactly a model citizen. The boy's lawyer outlined is background in his.closing statement. He was in prison once. He was known to be a compulsive gambler and a pretty consistent loser. .He spent a lot of time in neighborhood bars and he'd get into fist fights sometimes after a couple of drinks. Usually over a woman. He was a tough, cruel, primitive kind of man who never held a job for more than six months in his life. So here are a few possibilities. He could have been murdered by one of many men he served time with in prison. By a bookmaker. By a man he'd beaten up. By a woman he'd picked up. By any one of the rough characters he was known to hang out with.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Boy-oh-boy, that's the biggest load of crap I ever... Listen, we know the father was a bum. So what has that got to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: _ 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I didn't bring it up. I was asked who else might have killed him. I gave my answer.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (pointing at 4th Juror) That gentleman over there asked a direct question.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Everyone's a lawyer!

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Look, suppose you answer this for me. The old man who lived downstairs heard the kid yell out, "I'm going to kill you." A split second later he heard a body hit the floor. Then he saw the kid run out of the house. Now what does all that mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I was wondering how clearly the old man could have heard the boy's voice through the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: He didn't hear it through the ceiling. His window was open and so was the window upstairs. It was a hot night, remember?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: ’ The voice came from another apartment. It's not easy to identify a voice, especially a shouting voice.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: He identified it in court. He picked the boy's voice out of five other voices, blindfolded.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That was just an ambitious district attorney putting on a show. Look, the old man knows the boy's voice very well. They've lived in the same house for years. But to identify it positively from the apartment downstairs... Isn't it possible he was wrong -- that maybe he thought the boy was upstairs and automatically decided that the voice he heard was the boy's voice?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think that's a bit far-fetched.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: -Brother, you can say that again.  ~—— og SSS

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (to the 8th Juror) Look. The old man heard the father's body falling and then he saw the boy run out of the house fifteen seconds later. He saw the boy.

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: Check. And don't forget the woman across the street. She looked right into the open window and saw the boy stab his father. I mean, isn't that enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right now. No, it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: How do you like him? It's like talking into a dead phone.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The woman saw the killing through the windows of a moving elevated train. The train had six cars and she saw it through the windows of the last two cars. She remembered the most significant details. I don't see how you can argue with that.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 8th Juror) Well, what have you got to say about it?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know. It doesn't sound right to me.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, suppose you think about it. (to 12th Juror) Lend me your pencil The 12th Juror hands the pencil to 3rd Juror who starts t what is obviously a tic-tac-toe pattern on the pad.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I wonder if anybody has any idea how long it takes an elevated train...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 He sees 3rd Juror and 12th Juror playing tic-tac-toe, sna the pad, tears off the top sheet, crumples it and drops i waste basket. . -

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: This isn't a game.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (shouting) Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 3rd Juror) All right, take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Come on now, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I've got a good mind to belt him one.

dialogues.speaker: . FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Now, please! I don't want any fights in here.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Did you see him? The nerve! The absolute nerve!

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Forget it. It's not important. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: This isn't a game. Who does he think he's dealing with here?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Come on, now. It's all over. Let's take our seats.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What's all over? I want an apology.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: O.K., noisy. He apologizes. Now let's hear what the man has to say.  —— owe

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Thank you. I wonder if anybody has an idea how long it takes an elevated train going at medium. speed to pass a given point?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What has that got to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: How long? Take a guess.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have the slightest idea.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 5th Juror) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: STH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't know. About ten or twelve seconds, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What's all this for?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'd say that was a fair guess. Anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That sounds right to me.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on, what's the guessing game for?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 2nd Juror) What would you say?

dialogues.speaker: . 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Ten seconds. Approximately.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Say ten seconds. What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: This. It takes a six car el train ten seconds to pass a given point. Now say that given point is the open window of the room in which the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs. 50

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: killing took place. You can almost reach out ‘the window of that room and touch the el tracks. Right?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Now let me ask you this - - has anyone here ever lived right next to the el tracks?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I just finished painting an apartment that overlooked an el line. I'm a house painter, y'know. I was there for three days.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What was it like?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: -What d'ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Noisy?

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Brother! Well, it didn't matter. We're all punch in our business, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I lived in a second-floor apartment next to an el line once. When the window's open and the train goes by, the noise is almost unbearable. You can't hear yourself think.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay. You can't hear yourself think. Will you get to the point!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I will. Let's take two pieces of testimony and try to put them together. First, the old man in the apartment downstairs. He says he heard the boy say, "I'm going to kill you," and a split second later he

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: heard the. body hit the floor. One second later. Right?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: . 8TH JUROR ,
dialogues.text: Second, the woman in the apartment across the street. She claimed that she looked out of her window and saw the killing through the last two cars of a passing elevated train. Right? The last two cars.

dialogues.speaker: _ 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. What point are you making here? .

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now, we agreed that an el train takes about ten seconds to pass a given point. Since the woman saw the ‘stabbing through the last two cars we can assume that the boy fell to the floor just as the train passed by. Therefore, the el train had been roaring by the old man's window for a full ten seconds before the body fell. The old man, according to his own testimony, hearing "I'm going to kill you" and the body falling a split second later, would have had to hear the boy make this statement while the el was roaring past his nose. It's not possible that he could have heard it.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That's idiotic! Sure he could have heard it.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 3rd Juror) Do you think so?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: The old man said the boy yelled it out. That's enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: If he heard anything at all, he still couldn't have identified the voice with the el rearing by.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You're talking about a matter. of seconds here. Nobody can be that accurate.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I think that testimony which could put a human being into the electric chair should be that accurate. 5TH JUROR . I don't think he could have heard it.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe he didn't hear it. I mean, with the el noise...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What are you people talking about?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, it stands to reason...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You're crazy! Why should he lie? What's he got to gain?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Attention, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You keep coming up with these bright sayings. Why don't you send one in to a newspaper? They pay three dollars.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 3rd Juror) Hey! What're ya talking to him like that for? The 3rd Juror looks at the 6th Juror then turns disgusted The 6th Juror reaches out and turns the 3rd Juror firmly the arm.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: A guy who talks like that old man oughta really get stepped on y'know.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me!

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You oughta have some respect, mister. If you say stuff like that to him again -- I'm gonna lay you out. (he releases the 3rd Juror and speaks to the 9th Juror) Go ahead. You can say anything you want. Why do you think the old man might lie?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It's just that I looked at him fora very long time. The seam of his jacket was split under his arm. Did you notice it? I mean, to come into court like that. He was a very old man with a torn jacket and he walked very slowly to the stand. He was dragging his left leg and trying to hide it ‘because he was ashamed. I think I know him better than anyone here. This is a quiet, frightened, insignificant old man who has been nothing all his life, who has never had recognition, his name in the newspapers. Nobody knows him, nobody quotes him, nobody seeks his advice after seventy-five years. That's a very sad thing, to be nothing. A man like this needs to be recognized, to be listened to, to be quoted just once. This is very important. It would be so hard for him to recede Q into the background when there's a chance to be...

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now, wait a minute. Are you trying to tell us he'd lie just so that he could be important once?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. He wouldn't really lie. But perhaps he'd make himself believe that he'd heard those words and recognized the boy's face.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, that's the most fantastic story I've ever heard. How can you make up a think like that? what do you know about it? The 9th Juror lowers his head, embarrassed.  a a

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, let me remind you, this case is based on a reasonable and logical progression of facts. Let's keep it there.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Facts may be colored by the personalities of the people who present. them.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Anybody want a cough drop?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'll take one. (2nd Juror offers the cough. drops to the 8th Juror. 8th Juror takes one) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Say what you like, I still don't see how anybody can think the boy's not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: There's another think I wanted to talk about for a minute. I think we've proved that the old man couldn't have heard the boy say, "I'm going to kill you," but supposing...

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You didn't prove it at all. What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: But supposing he really did hear it. This phrase, how many times has each of us used it? Probably hundreds. "I could kill you for that, darling." "TE you do that once more, Junior, I'm going to kill you."  "'Come on, Rocky, kill him." We say it every day. It doesn't mean we're going to kill someone.  ~~ er

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! What are you trying to give us here? The phrase was, "I'm going to kill you," and the kid screamed it out at the top of his lungs. Don't tell me he didn't mean it. Anybody says a thing like that the way he said it, they mean it.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, gee, I don't know. I remember I was arguing with the guy I work next to at the bank a couple of weeks ago; so he called me an idiot; so I yelled at him...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Now listen, this guy is making you believe things that aren't so. The: kid said he was going to kill him and he did kill him.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, let me ask you this: do you really think the boy would shout out a thing like that so the whole neighborhood would hear it? I don't think so. He's much too bright for that.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Bright? He's a common ignorant slob. He’ don't even speak good English.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He doesn't even speak good English

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'd like to change my vote to "not guilty".

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now you've got to be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You heard.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure.  a RF

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: The vote is nine to three in favor of "guilty":

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, if that isn't the livin' end! What are you basing it on? Stories this guy made up. He oughta write for Amazing Detective Monthly. He'd make a fortune. (to Sth Juror) Listen, there are facts staring you right in your face. Every one of them says this kid killed his old man. For cryin' out loud his. own lawyer knew he didn't stand a chance right from the beginning. His own - lawyer. You could see it. He . deserves the chair.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
