dialogues.text: Does he? It’s happened before that someone’s been convicted of a murder, .and executed, and years later someone else has confessed to the crime. Sometimes... sometimes the facts that are staring everyone in the face are wrong. :

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 8th Juror) I'm talkin' to him -- (he indicates to the 5th Juror) not to you. (to the others) Boy, this guy is really something. (to the 8th Juror) Listen, the kid had a lawyer, didn’t he? The lawyer presented his case, not you. How come you've got so much to say?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The lawyér was court-appointed.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: So what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, it could mean a lot of things. It could mean he didn't want the case. It could mean he resented being appointed. It's the kind of case that brings him nothing. No

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: money. No glory. Not even much chance of winning. It's not a very promising situation for a young lawyer. He'd really have to believe in his client to put up a good fight. As you pointed out a minute ago, he obviously didn't.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure he didn't. Who in hell could, except God come to earth or somebody? (he looks at his watch then up at the clock) Come on already! Look at the time!

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Pardon me, but I have made some notes here.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Notes yet!

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I would like please to say something. I have been listening very closely, and it seems to me that this man -- (he indicates the 8th Juror) has some very good points to make. From what was presented at the trial the boy looks guilty, but maybe if we go deeper...

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on, will ya.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: There is a question I would like to ask. We assume that the boy committed murder. He stabbed his father in the chest and ran away. This was at ten minutes after twelve. Now, how was he caught by the police? He came home at three o'clock or so and was captured by two detective in the hallway of his house. My question is, if he really had killed his father, why would he come back three hours later? Wouldn't he be afraid of being caught?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Look -- he came home to get his knife. It's not nice to leave knives sticking around in people's chests.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, especially relatives.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't see anything funny about it. (to the 11th Juror) The boy knew that there were people who could identify the knife as the one he had just bought. He had to get it before the police did.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: But if he knew the knife could be identified, why did he leave it there in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I think we can assume he ran out in a state of panic after he killed his father, and then when he finally calmed down, he realized that he had left the knife there.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: This then depends on your definition of panic. He was calm enough to see to-it that there were no fingerprints on the knife. Now where did his panic. start and where did it end?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Look, you can forget all that other stuff. He still came home to dig out his knife and get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Three hours later?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure, three hours later.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: If I were the boy and I had killed my father, I would not have come home three hours later. I would be afraid that the police would be there. I would stay away, knife or no knife.  — =

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, you voted "guilty", didn't you? What side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't believe I have to be loyal to one side or the other. I am simply asking questions.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, this is just off the top of my head, but if I were the boy, and I'd, you know, done the stabbing and everything, I'd take a chance and go back for the knife. I'll bet he figured no one had seen him and that the body probably wasn't even discovered yet. After all, it was the middle of the night. He probably thought no one would find the boy till the next day.”

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Pardon. Here.is my whole point. . The woman across the street testified that a moment after she saw the killing, that is, a moment after the el train went by, she screamed and then went to telephone the police. Now, the boy must certainly have heard that scream and known that somebody saw something. I don't think he would have gone back if he had been the murderer.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Two points. One: in his state of panic he may not have heard the scream. Perhaps it wasn't very loud. . Two: if he did hear it, he may not have connected it with his own act. Remember he lived in a neighborhood where screams were fairly commonplace.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Right! There's your answer.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe he did stab his father, didn't hear the woman's scream, did run out in a panic, did calm down three hours later and come back to try to get the knife, risking being  —— oe ee

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR., (CONT)
dialogues.text: caught by the police. Maybe all those things are so. But maybe they're not. I think there's enough doubt to make us wonder whether he was there at all during the time the murder took place.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What d'ya mean doubt? What are you talking about? didn't the old man see him running out of the house? He's twisting the facts. I'm telling you! (to the 11th Juror) Did or didn't the old man see the kid running out of the house at twelve- ten? Well, did he or didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He says he did.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Says he did! (to the others) Boy-oh-boy! How do you like that? (to the 11th Juror) Well, did or didn't the woman across the street see the kid kill his father? She says she did. You're makin' out like it don't matter what people say. What you want to believe, you believe, and what you don't want to believe, so you don't. What kind of way is that? What d'ya think these people get up on the witness stand for -- their health? I'm telling you men the facts are being changed around here. Witnesses are being doubted and there's no reason for it.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Witnesses can make mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure, when you want ‘em to, they do! Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's hold the yelling down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jurors who are 61

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You keep- saying that. Maybe what we need is a little yelling in here. These guys are going off every which way. Did hear the scream, didn't hear the scream. What's the difference? they're just little details. You're forgetting the important stuff. I mean, all of a sudden here everybody...

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'd like to call for another vote.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm talking here.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: There's another vote called for. Now - about taking seats. standing move toward their seats.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What are we gonna gain by voting again?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. The gentleman asked...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I never saw so much time spent on nothing.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: (mildly) It only takes a second.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. I guess the fastest way is to find out who's voting not guilty. All those in favor of not guilty raise their hands. 5th, 8th and 9th Jurors raise their hands.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Still the same. One, two, three not guilty's. Nine guilty's.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: So now where are we? I'm telling you, we can yakety-yak until next Tuesday here. Where's it getting us?  CS —_— ar

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Pardon. (hé slowly raises his hand) I vote not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Oh, brother!

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Oh, now listen! What are you talking about? I mean, we're all going crazy in here or something! This kid is guilty. Why don'tcha pay attention to the facts. (to 4th Juror) Listen, tell him, will ya? This is getting to be a goddamn joke!

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: The vote is eight to four, favor of guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I mean, everybody's heart is starting to bleed for this punk little kid like the President just declared it "Love Your Underprivileged Brother Week", or something. (to 11th Juror) Listen, I'd like you to tell me why you changed your vote. Come one, give me reasons.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't have to defend my decision to you. I have a reasonable doubt in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What reasonable doubt? That's nothing but words. (he pulls out the switch-knife from the table and holds it ‘up) Here, look at this. The kid you just decided isn't guilty was seen ramming this thing into his father. Well, look at it, Mr. Reasonable Doubt.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH. JUROR
dialogues.text: That's not the knife. Don't you remember?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Brilliant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sticks the knife into the table.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' ya, this is the craziest. (to the 8th Juror) I mean, you're sittin’ in here pulling stories outta thin air. What're we supposed to believe? (to the others) I'm telling you, if this guy was sitting ringside at the Dempsey-Firpo fight, he'd be tryin' to tell us Firpo won. (to the 8th Juror) -Look, what about the old man?. Are we supposed to believe that he didn't | get up and run to his door and see the kid tearing down the stairs , fifteen seconds after the killing? He's only saying he did to be important. I mean, what's the point of the whole.:.?

dialogues.speaker: . 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: } i Hold it a second.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: And the Milwaukee rooter is heard from. And pop-ups are falling for base hits wherever we look. I tell you...

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Did the old man say he ran to the door?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Ran. Walked. What’s the difference? He got there.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He said he ran to the door. At least, I think he did.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't remember what he said. But I don't see how he could run. eet entiaaaae

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he went from his bedroom to : the front door. That's enough, isn't | it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: —— =F aS

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRAFT
dialogues.text: He goes to the 64

dialogues.speaker: _ 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where was his bedroom, again?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Down the hall somewhere. I thought you remembered everything. Don't you remember that?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. Mr. Foreman, I'd like to take a look at the diagram of the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Why don't we have them run the trial over just so you can get everything straight?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Mr. Foreman...

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: I heard you. door and knocks. The Guard enters. The Foreman confers briefly with him. The Guard exits and locks the d him.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: All right, what's this for? How come you're the only one in the room who wants to see exhibits all the time?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I want to see his one, too.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: And I want to stop wasting time.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I£ we're going to start wading through all that business about where the body was found...

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: We're not. Not unless someone else wants to. I'd like to see if a very old man who drags one leg when he walks because he had a stroke last year can get from his bed to his front door in fifteen seconds.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: He said twenty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He said fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm telling you he said twenty. What're you trying to distort...

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He said fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: How does he know how long fifteen seconds is? You can't judge that kind of thing. .

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He said fifteen seconds. He was very positive about it..

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: He's an old man. You saw him. Half the time he was confused. How could he be positive about anything. The Guard enters carrying a large diagram of the apartmen diagram is a layout of a railroad flat. A bedroom faces t tracks. Behind it is a series of rooms off a long hall. I front room is an "X" marking the spot where the body was the back of the apartment we see the entrance into the ap hall from the building hall. We see a flight of stairs in building hall. Each room is labeled and the dimensions of room are shown. Foreman takes diagram. Guard exits.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don't see what we're going to prove here. The man said he saw the boy running out.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, let's see if the details bear him out. As soon as the body fell to the floor, he said, he heard footsteps upstairs running towards the front door. He heard the upstairs door open and the footsteps start down the stairs. He got to his front door as soon as he could. He swore that it couldn't have been more than fifteen seconds. Now, if the killer began running immediately...

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: The old man said he did.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You know, you ought to be down in Atlantic City at the hair-splitters' convention.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, baseball, why don't you stop making smart remarks all the time?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: My friend, for your three dollars a day you've gotta listen to - everything.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 8th Juror) Well, now that you've got that thing in here, what about it?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to Foreman) May I? (he takes the plan and puts it on a chair) This is the apartment in which the killing took place. The old man's apartment is directly beneath it and exactly the same. Here are the el tracks. The bedroom. Another bedroom. Bathroom. Living room. Kitchen. And this is the hall. Here's the front door to the apartment. And here are the stairs. Now, the old man was in bed in this room. (he indicates the front bedroom) He says he got up, went out into the hall, down the hall to the front door, opened it and looked out just in time to see the boy racing down the stairs. Am I right so far?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That's the story, for the nineteenth time.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Fifteen seconds after he heard the body fall. :

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: His bed was at the window... It's... (he looks closely at the plan) ...twelve feet from his bed to the bedroom door. The length of the hall is forty-three feet, six inches. Now,. he had to get up out of bed, walk twelve feet, open the bedroom door, walk forty-three feet and open the front door -- all in fifteen seconds. Do you think he could have done it?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Sure he coulda done it.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He can only walk very slowly. They had to help him into the witness chair.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You make it sound like a long walk. It's not.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: For an old man who had a stroke it's a long walk. The 8th Juror moves his chair and sets the chair to indic

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I want to try this thing. Let's see how long it took him.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What d'you mean you want to try it? Why didn't the kid's lawyer bring it up if it's so important?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, maybe he just didn't think of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68 ‘ 10TH JUROR What d'ya.mean he didn't think of it? You think the man's an idiot or something. It's an obvious thing.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Did you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, smart’ guy. It don't matter whether I thought of it.

dialogues.speaker: " FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, now... let's hold it down.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He didn't bring it up because he knew the answer'd hurt his case. Now what d’ya think of that?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It's possible that he didn't bring it up because it would have meant badgering and bullying a helpless old man, something that I don't think sits very well with a jury. Most lawyers avoid that kind of thing if they can.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: So what kind of a bum is he, then?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That's what I've been asking. All right. Let's say these chairs are the old man's bed. I'm going to pace off twelve feet, the length of the bedroom. He paces twelve feet.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You're crazy. You can't re-create a thing like that.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'd like to see it.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Someone hand me a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 12th Juror pick sup his chair and takes it to 8th Jur Juror puts the chair where he is standing.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: All right, this is the bedroom door. The hall is a little over forty-three feet long. I'll pace over to that wall and back again. He paces counting his steps silently.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Look, this is absolutely insane. What's the idea of wasting everybody's time here?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: ...twelve... (he stops and turns to the 10th Juror) According to you it'll only take fifteen seconds. We can spare that... He resumes his pacing, counting to himself, and reaches t The others watch silently. He turns and paces, counting o rest of the distance.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: ...thirty nine, forty, forty-one, forty-two, forty-three. Okay, pass me another chair, please. 6th Juror picks up a chair and takes it to 8th Juror. 8th places it where he is standing.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: This is the door to the outside hall and stairway. It was chain-locked according to the testimony. Who's got a watch with a second hand?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: When you want me to start, stamp your foot. That'll be the body falling. Time me from there. He lies down on the two chairs.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: -*  Bnyone for charades?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I've never seen anything like this in my whole life!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm ready. The 2nd Juror stares at his watch, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on, let's go here.

dialogues.speaker: . 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: I want to wait until the second hand reaches sixty. They wait. The 2nd Juror suddenly stamps his foot. The 8t rises to a sitting position, swings his legs to the floor stands up. The 2nd Juror keeps his eyes on his watch. The Juror hobbles, dragging one leg, towards the chair which the bedroom door. He reaches it and pretends to open the then hobbles along the simulated forty-three-foot hallway

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on. Snap it up. He walked twice as fast as that. 11TH JUROR . This is, I think, even more quickly than the old man walked in the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (still hobbling) If you think I should go faster, I will. He speeds up his pace slightly, reaches the wall, turns a for the second chair, the one simulating the door to the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Come on, will ya! Let's get this kid stuff over with. They watch as the 8th Juror reaches the last chair. He pr open an imaginary chain lock and then opens the imaginary

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What's the time?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND_ JUROR
dialogues.text: Fifteen -- twenty -- thirty -- thirty-five -- forty -- forty-two seconds exactly.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Forty-two seconds!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think this is what happened. The old man heard the fight between the boy and his father a few hours earlier. Then, while lying in bed, he heard a body hit the floor in the boy's apartment, and he heard the woman scream from across the street. He got up, tried to get to the door, heard someone racing down the stairs, and assumed it was the boy.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think that's possible.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Assumed? Now listen to me, you people. I've seen all kinds of dishonesty in my day -- but this little display takes the cake. You come in here with your sanctimonious talk about slum kids and. injustice, and you make up some wild stories, and all of a sudden you start getting through to some of these old ladies in here. Well, you're not getting through to me. I've had enough. What's the matter with you people? Every one of you knows this kid is guilty. He's got to burn. We're letting him slip through our fingers here.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Slip through our fingers? Are you his executioner?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd like to pull the switch.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: For this kid? You bit I'd like to pull the switch.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Don't start with me now.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Ever since we walked into this room you've been behaving like a self- -appointed public avenger.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm telling you now! Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You want to see this boy die because you personally want it, not because of the facts.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You're a sadist!

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Shut up, you son of a bitch! He lunges wildly at 8th Juror. The 8th Juror holds his ground. The 5th and 6th Jurors gr 3rd Juror from behind. He strains against the hands, his with rage.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Let go of me, God damn it! I'll kill him! I'11 kill him!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (calmly) You don't really mean you'll kill me, do you? The 3rd juror breaks from the Sth and 6th jurors, stops s and stares bitterly at the 8th Juror. . There is silence. The 3rd Juror crosses to the window. Th Jurors move about the room. There is an awkward silence. Guard enters. :

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Is there anything wrong, gentlemen? _I heard some noise.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: No. There's nothing wrong. (he collects the apartment plan, ~ from the table) Just a little argument. Everything's okay. . (He hands the plan to the Guard) We're finished with this. The Guard takes the plan, looks carefully around the room exits. There is a pause. The others look at the 3rd juror

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what are you staring at? The others, embarrased, turn away. Someof them take their

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, -- I suppose someone has to -- start it off again.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: It's getting late (to the Foreman) What do they do, take us out toa restaurant for supper?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: How do I know?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: I wonder if they let us go home in case we can't finish tonight. I've got a boy with mumps. He's out of here. The wife says he looks like Khrushchev. The room begins to darken perceptibly now. 11TH JUROR . Pardon. This fighting. This is not why we are here, to fight. We have a responsibility. This, I have always thought, is a remarkable thing about democracy. That we are, uh, what is the word? Notified. That we are notified by mail to come down to this place and decide on the guilt or innocence of a man we have never

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 4th Juror, heat at all. No-one answers 74

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR

An important point for the prosecution was the fact that the boy, after he claimed he was at the movies during the hours the killing took place, couldn't name the pictures he saw or the stars who appeared in them. (he points to the 4th Juror) This gentleman has repeated that point in here several times.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR

I'll take the testimony of the policeman who interrogated him right after the murder, when he couldn't remember a thing about the movies, great emotional stress or not.

dialogues.text: (straining) The... I'll tell you in a minute. The -- Remarkable Mrs. Something. Mrs. -- uh -- Mainbridge. No, Bainbridge. The Remarkable Mrs. Bainbridge.

Being accused of murder isn’t necessarly supposed to give him an infallible memory.

dialogues.text: (te the 9th Juror) You can talk till your tongue is draggin’ on the floor. The boy is guilty. -Period. Know what I mean, my fiend? Who’s got. those cough drops?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: What I was gonna say was, the psychiatrist definitely stated that the boy had strong homicidal tendencies. I mean, that he was, what d’ya call it -- capable of committing murder. He described all those tests, inkblots and all that stuff, and he said the kid is definitely a killer-type. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Check. I think he said something about paranoid tendencies if I’m not mistaken.

dialogues.text: Right. Whatever that is, he said it. Let's not forget, we’re talking about a. boy who’s always had murder on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: His unconscious mind.

dialogues.speaker: . FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Nobody else's.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I beg pardon, in discussing...

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: For the same reason you’re not. It’s the way I was brought up. (he turns to the others) In discussing such a thing as the murder potential we should remember that many of us are capable of committing murder. But few of us do. We impose controls upon ourselves to prevent it. The most these psychiatric tests can accomplish

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops. The 90

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: along these lines is this: They can tell us that some day a particular person may commit a murder. That’s all. They prove nothing.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Then how come they're admitted in evidence?

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: They have many uses, of course. In this case they added to the general impression the prosecution was trying to create. Perhaps we would find that if we twelve men took the same tests, one or two of us might be discovered to have.unconscious desires to kill, and the potentiality of carrying them out. Yet none of us has. To say that a man is capable of murder does not mean that he has committed murder.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: But it can mean it. Listen, if they said the kid is capable of killing, he could’ve killed, couldn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You're the one who said, and I quote, “I wouldn’t give you a nickel for a psychiatrist’s testimony.

dialogues.text: Boy, I’m telling you -- (he crosses to the 8th juror) I'd like to... 8th Juror does not look up at him. The 10th Juror crosses angrily away.

dialogues.text: Um -- there’s something I’d like to say. I mean, it’s been bothering me a little and as long as we're stuck Well, there was this whole busin about the stab wound and how it was made, the downward angle of it, you know?

dialogues.text: Don’t tell me we’re gonna start with that. They went over it and over it.

dialogues.text: I know they did, but I don’t go along with it. The boy is five feet, seven inches tall. His father was six-two. That's a difference of seven inches. It’s a very awkward thing to stab down into. the chest of someone who's more than a half a foot taller than you are.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (crossing to 2nd Juror and indicating the knife) Give me that. ° The 2nd Juror hands the knife to the 3rd Juror.

dialogues.text: Look you’re not gonna be satisfied till you see it again. I’m gonna give you a:demonstration. Somebody get up. There is a pause. No one moves for a moment, and then the Juror rises and crosses to the 3rd Juror. They stand look each other. .

dialogues.text: Okay. (to the 2nd Juror) Now, watch this. I don’t want to ‘have to do it. again. (he turns to the 8th Juror, looks squarely at him, and squats to make himself shorter) I'm six or seven inches shorter than you. Right?

dialogues.text: Okay. Let it be more. He flicks open the knife, changes its position in his han holds it aloft, ready to stab downwards. The 8th Juror and the 3rd Juror look steadily at each oth the 3rd Juror suddenly stabs downward, hard.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: Look out! The blade stops about an inch from the 8th Juror’s chest. Juror does not move. The 3rd Juror smiles.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH
dialogues.text: That's not funny.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD. JUROR
dialogues.text: Now just calm down. Nobody’s hurt. Right?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. Nobody’s hurt.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. There's your angle. Take a look at it. Down and in. That's how I'd stab a taller man in the chest and that’s how it was done. Now go ahead and tell me I’m wrong. The 3rd Juror hands the knife to the 8th Juror and crosse The 12th Juror crosses to the 8th Juror and using his clo simulates stabbing the 8th Juror in the chest.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Down and in. I guess there’s no argument.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (moving to the 8th Juror) Wait a minute. Give me that. The 8th Juror hands the knife to the 5th Juror. He closes knife and holds it gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: I hate these things. I grew up with them.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Have you seen them used in fights?

dialogues.speaker: . 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Too many of them. On my stoop. In my backyard. In the lot across the street. Switch knives came with the neighborhood where I lived. Funny, I wasn’t thinking of it. I guess you try to forget those things. You can’t use this kind of knife that way. You have to hold it like this

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: to release the blade. In order to stab downwards, you would have to change your grip.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: How do you use it?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Underhanded. He flicks the knife open and holding it underhanded, swin and slashes swiftly forward and upward.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Like that. Anyone who's ever used a switch knife’d never handle it any other way.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I’m sure. (He closes the blade and flicks it open again) That’s why they’re made like this.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Everyone agreed that the boy is pretty handy with a knife, didn’t they?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 5th Juror) Do you think he would have made the kind of wound that killed his father?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Not with the experience he’d had with these things. No, I don’t think he would. He’d go for him underhanded...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: How do you know? What -- were you in the room when the father was killed?

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No, and neither was anyone else. He sticks the knife in the table and crosses away.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: - (to the 8th Juror) You're giving us a lot of mumbo-jumbo here. I don’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don’t think you can determine what type of wound this boy might or might not have made simply because he knows how to handle a knife.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That‘s right.  That’s absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking at the 12th juror) What do you think? The 12th Juror hesitates for a moment. He is confused, bu to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well -- I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What d’ya mean -- you don’t know?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 7th Juror) What about you? The 7th Juror looks around the table momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Just a minute. According to the woman across the street...

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, I/1l1 tell you something. I’m a little sick of this whole thing already. All this yakkin’s gettin’ us nowhere so I'm going to break it up here. I’m changing my vote to not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You’re what?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You heard me. I’ve had enough.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What d’you mean -- you’ve had enough? That’s no answer.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Hey, listen, you! Just worry about yourself!

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (crossing to the 7th Juror) He’s right. That is not an answer. What kind of a man are you? You have sat here and voted guilty with everyone else because there are some baseball tickets burning a hole in your pocket. Now you have changed your vote because you say you're sick of all the talking here.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, buddy...

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You have no right to play like this with a man’s life. This is a terrible and ugly thing to do. Don’t you care...?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. You can’t talk like that to me!  -we

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I can talk like that to you. If you want to vote not guilty, then do it because you’re convinced the man is not guilty -- not because you’ve had enough. And if you think he’s guilty then vote that way. Or don’t you have the guts to do what you think is right?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now, listen...

dialogues.speaker: " 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Guilty or not guilty?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I told you -- not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: God damn you. I don’t have to...

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You do have to. Say it. Why?

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (in a low voice) I -- don’t think he’s guilty. The 11th Juror looks disgustedly at the 7th Juror then mo chair. The 7th Juror stands defeated.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Mr. Foreman, I want another vote.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, there’s another vote called for. (the Jurors cross to their chairs and sit) I guess the quickest way is a show of - : hands. Anybody object? (there is no answer) All those voting not guilty raise your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 2nd, 5th, 6th, 7th, Sth 9th and Lith Jurors raise the immediately.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: One. Two. Three. Four. Five. Six. Seven. The 12th Juror’s face is a mask of indecision, then he su raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: eight. He stops counting and.looks around the table. Slowly, alm embarrassed he raises his own hand

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Nine. (he lowers his hand) All those voting guilty. The 3rd, 4th, and 10th Jurors raise their hands.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Nine to three in favor of not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don’t understand you people. I mean, all these picky little points you keep bringing up. They don’t mean nothing. How can you believe his story? (to the 11th Juror) You’re an intelligent man. Well, you’re not gonna tell me you’re not. - You know the facts of life. Well, for chrissakes look at what we’re dealing with here. You know him! I mean, that guy -- (he points to the 8th Juror) over there, well, I don’t know what the hell is going on with him. All that talk about psychiatrists. Maybe he ought to go to one. Look, let’s talk facts. These people are born to lie. Now it’s the way they are and no intelligent man is gonna tell me otherwise. They don’t know what the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 5th Juror The 5th Juror 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: truth is. Well, take a look at them. They are different. They think different. They act different. Well, for instance, they don’t need any big excuse to kill someone. crosses to the washroom door.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Well, that’s true. Everybody knows it. They get drunk on wine or | something cheap like that. Oh, they’re very big drinkers. goes into the washroom, slams the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR., (CONT)
dialogues.text: Smart guy! Look at him for chrissakes! What does that mean, slamming the door? And then they're drunk, and all of a sudden -- bang -- somebody's lying dead in the gutter. Okay, nobody’s blaming them for it. That’s how they are, by nature, y'know what I mean? Violent! Human life don’t mean as much to them as it does to us. The 11th Juror rises and crosses to the washroom door. He the 11th Juror. .

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Where are you going. The 11th juror does not reply and goes into the washroom. The 4th Juror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you’re in there, clean out your ears, maybe you'll hear something. rises and moves to the window.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Look, you,listen to me now. These people are boozing it up, and fighting all the time, and if somebody gets killed, so somebody gets killed. They don’t care. Family don’t mean anything to them. They breed like animals. Fathers, mothers, that don’t mean anything. Oh, sure, there are some good things about’em. Look, I’m the first one to say that. I’ve known some who were okay, but that’s the exception.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Do you know that you’re a sick man?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Sick?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Why don’t you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You old son of a bitch! Who the hell are you? He moves towards the 9th Juror. The 12th Juror steps betw 9th and the 10th Jurors.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: (to the 12th juror) No. Who the hell is he to tell me that? Sick. Look at him - he can hardly stand up. Listen, I’m speaking my piece here and you’re gonna listen. The 9th Juror moves to the window.

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe if you just quieted down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 10TH JUROR . I will like hell quite down. There is not one of them, not one who’s any good. Now d’you hear that? Not one. Now let me lay this out for you -- ignorant -- bastards. (to the 9th Juror) You at the window, you're so god- damned smart. We're facing a danger here. Don’t you know it?. These people are multiplying. That kid on trial, his type, they’re multiplying five times as fast as we are. That’s the statistic. Five times. And they are -- wild animals. They're against us, they hate us, they want to destroy us. That's right. (to 6th Juror) Don't look at me like that! There’s a danger. For God’s sake we’re living in a dangerous time, and if we don’t watch it, if we don’t smack them down whenever we can, then they are gonna own us. They’re gonna breed us out of existence.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Ah, shut up!

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now you god-damned geniuses had better listen to me. They’re violent, they’re vicious, they’re ignorant, and they will cut us up. That’s their intent. To cut us up. (to 7th Juror) I'm warning you. This boy, this. boy on trial here. We've got him. That’s one at least. I say get him before his kind gets us. I don’t give a god-damn about the law. Why should I? They don’t. Now I'm telling you.  -~ wr =

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: I’ve heard enough. Now you just stop all this.

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking angrily at the 2nd Juror) How would you like me to cave your head in for you, you smart little bastard? Where the hell do you get the gall...? . The 4th Juror steps in front of the 10th Juror and stops firmly.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: We've heard enough. Sit down. And don’t open your filthy mouth again. The 4th and 10th Jurors stare at each other. Finally, the Juror turns away, crosses to a chair and sits his back to others. The other Jurors slowly cross to their seats.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It’s very hard to keep personal prejudice out of a thing like this. And no matter where you run into it, prejudice obscures the truth. Well, I don’t think any real damage has been done here. Because I don’t really know what the truth is. No one ever will, I suppose. Nine of us now seem to feel that the defendant is innocent, but we're just gambling on probabilities. We may be wrong. We may be trying to return a guilty man to the community. No one can really know. But we have a reasonable doubt, and this is a safeguard which has enormous value in our system. No jury can declare a man guilty unless it’s sure. We nine can’t understand how you three are still so sure. Maybe you can tell us.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I’ll try.. You’ve made some excellent points. The last one, in which you “proved” that the boy couldn’t have made the kind of overhand stab would that killed his father, was very persuasive. But I still believe the boy is guilty of murder. I have two reasons. One: the evidence given by the woman across the street who actually saw the murder committed.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: And how, brother! As far as I’m concerned that’s the most important testimony .in the whole case.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: And two: the fact that this woman described the stabbing by saying she saw the boy raise his arm over his head and plunge the knife down. into his father’s chest. She saw him do it -- the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That’s right! That’s absolutely right!

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Now, let’s talk about this woman for a minute. She said that she went to bed at about eleven o’clock that night. Her bed was next to the window -- and she could look out while lying down and see directly into the boy’s window across the street. ‘She tossed and turned for over an hour, unable to fall asleep. Finally, she turned towards the window at about ten minutes after twelve, and, as she looked out, she saw the killing through the windows

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: of the passing el train. She says that the lights went out immediately after the killing but that she got a good look at the boy in the act of stabbing his father. As far as I can see, this is unshakable testimony.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: That’s what I mean. That's the whole case.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 8th Juror) What do you think? The 8th Juror remains silent. The 4th Juror looks at the Juror.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: How about you?

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: Well -- I don’t know. There’s so much evidence to sift. This isa pretty complicated business.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Frankly I don’t see how we can vote for acquittal.

dialogues.speaker: JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, it’s not easy to arrange the evidence in order.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You can throw out all the other evidence. The woman saw him do it. What else. do you want?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, maybe...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Let’s vote on it.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Okay. There’s another vote called for. Anybody object?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I’m changing my vote. I think he’s “guilty”.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Anybody else? The vote is eight to four.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 3rd juror) What makes you consider this one vote a personal triumph?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I’m the competitive type. (to the others) Okay. Now here’s what I think. I think we’re a hung jury. Let’s take it inside to the judge.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: You didn’t want a hung jury before.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, I want it now. 4TH JUROR . I don’t understand that. You thought it was immoral to...

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I don’t any more. There are people in here who are so god-damned stubborn that you can’t even... We’11 never get this thing done. We'll be here for a week. Well, I want to hear an argument. I say we're a hung jury. (he turns to the 8th Juror) Come on. You're the leader of the cause. What about it?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Let's go over it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: worry oS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went over it again. (he waves towards the 12th Juror) J. Walter Thompson up there is bouncing backwards and forwards like a tennis ball...

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Wait a second. You have no right to... The 4th Juror removes his spectacles and polishes them.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I apologize on my knees. (to the 8th Juror) Come on. lLet’s get out from under this thing.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. Maybe we can talk about setting some kind of a time limit. Still polishing his spectacles, he turns and peers up at

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: The time is... He squints and puts on his spectacles.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Quarter after six.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (looking at clock) - Quarter after six. He removes his spectacles and lays themon the table. He l tired. He closes his eyes and clasps his fingers over the left by his spectacles at the sides of his nose. He rubs areas as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Someone before mentioned seven o'clock. I think that’s a point at which we might begin to discuss the question of whether we’re a hung jury or not.  Sa ea ee

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRAFT
dialogues.text: The 9th Juror looks closely at the 4th Juror and obviousl thought of something tremendously exciting.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 4th juror) Don’t you feel well?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I feel perfectly well -- thank you. (to the others) I was saying that seven o’clock would be a reasonable time to... “9TH JUROR The reason I asked about that was because you were rubbing your nose like... I’m sorry for interrupting. But you made a gesture that reminded me... :

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm trying to settle something here. Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I think this is important.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Very well.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’m sure you'll pardon me for this, but I was wondering why you were rubbing your nose like that?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Ah, come on, now, will ya please!

dialogues.speaker: . 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Right now I happen to be talking to this gentleman here. (to the 4th Juror) Now, why were you rubbing your nose?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, if it's any of your business, I was rubbing it because it bothers me a little.  veo oS

dialogues.speaker: FIRST DRAFT
dialogues.text: ry 108

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Is it because of your eyeglasses?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It is. Now. could we get on to something else?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Your eyeglasses make those deep impressions on the sides of your nose. I hadn’t noticed that before. They must be annoying.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: They are very annoying. 9TH JUROR . . I. wouldn’t know about that. I’ve never worn eyeglasses. (he points to-his eyes and smiles) Twenty-twenty.

dialogues.speaker: 7TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Listen, will you come on already with the optometrist bit.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 4th juror) The woman who testified that she saw the killing had these same deep marks on the sides of her nose. There is a silence in the room and then a babble of ad li conversation.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: Please. Just a minute and then I’11 be finished. I don’t know if anyone else noticed that about her. I didn’t think about it then, but I’ve been going over her face in my mind. She had those marks. She kept rubbing them in court.

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: He's right. She did do that a lot.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: This woman was about forty-five years old. SHe was making tremendous effort to look thirty-five for her first public appearance. Heavy make- up. Dyed hair. Brand-new clothes that should have been worn by a younger woman. No eyeglasses. See if you can get a mental picture of her.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR. _
dialogues.text: What d’ya mean, no glasses? You don’t know if she wore glasses. Just because she was rubbing her nose...

dialogues.speaker: 5TH JUROR
dialogues.text: She had those marks. I saw ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: So what? What d’ya think that means?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Listen, I saw ‘em too. He’s. right. I was the closest one to her. She had these deep things, what d’ya call ‘em, uh -- you know. He messages the spot: on his nose where they should be.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what point are you making here?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: She had those marks.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: She had dyed hair and marks on her nose. I’m asking ya what does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Could those marks be made by anything other than eyeglasses?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No. They couldn’t.  110

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: (tq the 4th. Juror) Listen, what are you saying here? I didn’t see any marks.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I did. Strange, but I didn’t think about it before.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what about the lawyer? Why didn’t he say anything?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: There are twelve people in here concentrating on this case. Eleven of us didn’t think of it either. -

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay, Clarence Darrow. Then what about the District Attorney? You think he’d try to pull a trick like that, have her testify without glasses?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Did you ever see a woman who had to wear glasses and didn’t want to because she thinks they spoil her looks.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: My wife. Listen, I’m telling ya, as soon as we walk outta the house...

dialogues.speaker: . 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Maybe the District Attorney didn't know, either.

dialogues.speaker: 6TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s what I was just gonna say.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Okay. She had marks on her nose. I’m givin’ ya this. From glasses. Right? She never wore ‘em out of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: le Mt

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: house so people’d think she was gorgeous. But when she saw this kid kill his father she was in the e house. Alone. That’s all.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to 4th Juror) Do you wear your eyeglasses when you go to bed?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No, I don’t. No one wears eyeglasses to bed.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It's logical to say that she wasn’t wearing them while she was in bed, tossing and turning, trying to fall asleep. 3RD JUROR i How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m guessing. I’m also guessing that she probably didn’t put on her glasses when she turned and looked casually out of the window. And she herself said that the murder took place just ass he looked out, and the lights went off a split second later. She couldn’t have had time to put glasses on then.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Wait a second...

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: And here’s another guess. Maybe she honestly thought she saw the boy kill his father. I say that she saw only a blur.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: How do you know what she saw? How does he know all these things? (to 8th Juror) You don’t know what kind of glasses she wore. Maybe she was farsighted. Maybe they were sunglasses. What do you know about it?

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I only know that the woman’s eyesight is in question now.

dialogues.speaker: 11TH JUROR
dialogues.text: She had to identify a person sixty feet away in the dark, without glasses.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: You cant send someone off to die on evidence like that.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Don’t give me that!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Don’t you think that the woman might have made a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It’s not possible?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: No! It’s not possible.

dialogues.speaker: . 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 12th Juror) Is it possible?

dialogues.speaker: 12TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yes. I say not guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 10th Juror) Do you think he’s guilty?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Yes, I think he’s guilty. But I couldn’t care less. You smart bastards do whatever you want to do.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: How do you vote?

dialogues.speaker: 10TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Not guilty. Do whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: You’re the worst son a... I think he’s guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: Does anyone else think he’s guilty?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: No, I’m convinced.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: I now have a reasonable doubt.

dialogues.speaker: 9TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It’s eleven to one.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what about all the other evidence? What about all that stuff -- the knife -- the whole business?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND JUROR
dialogues.text: You said we could throw out all the other evidence.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: (to the 3rd Juror) You're alone.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I don’t care whether I’m alone or not. It’s my right.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It’s your right.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Well, what d’ya want? I say he’s guilty.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: We want your arguments.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: I gave you my arguments.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: We're not convinced. We want to hear them again. We have as much time as it takes.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: Everything -- every single thing that came out in that courtroom, but I mean everything, says he’s guilty. Do you think I’m an idiot or something? You lousy bunch of bleeding hearts. You're not goin’ to intimidate me. I’m entitled to my opinion. I can sit in this goddamn room for a year. Somebody say something. (the others watch silently) Why doncha take that stuff about the old man -- the old man who lived there -- and heard everything. Or take the knife, what -- just because he -- found one like it? The old man saw him. Right there on the stairs. What's the difference how many seconds it took? What's the difference? Every single thing. The knife falling through a hold in his pocket -- you can’t prove that he didn’t get to the door. Sure you can hobble around the room all. you want, but you can’t prove. it. I’m telling you every single thing that went on has been twisted and turned in here. That business with the glasses, how do you know she didn’t have them on?

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR, (CONT)
dialogues.text: The woman testified in court. Well, what d’/ya want? That's it. (the others are silent) That’s the whole case. (the others are silent) That whole thing about hearing the boy yell? The Phrase was “I’m gonna kill you.” That’s what he said. To his own father. I don’t care what kind of a man that was. It was his father. That goddamn rotten kid. I know him. What they’re like. What they do to you. How they kill you every day. My God, don’t you see? How come I’m the only one who sees? Jeez, I can feel that knife goin’ in.

dialogues.speaker: 8TH JUROR
dialogues.text: It’s not your boy. He’s somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: 4TH JUROR
dialogues.text: let him live. There’s a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: 3RD JUROR
dialogues.text: All right. “Not guilty.” The. foreman moves to the door and knocks on it. The guar

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: We're ready.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen. Bring your coats and come along. The Guard exits.. The foreman and the other Jurors collec jackets etc., and follow him off. The 3rd Juror remains s Finally only he and the 8th. Juror remain in the room. Th Juror puts on his own jacket and brings the 3rd Juror’s j him. 3rd Juror rises. 8th Juror helps him on with his jac Juror exits. 8th Juror follows, but pauses at the door an back at the empty Jury room. The knife still sticks into table. The 8th Juror exits. The rain has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the courthouse building, shooting from outsid beats against it. It begins to turn now, and the jurors s emerge. One by one they walk into the rain, each reacting own maneuvers. One turns up his collar. One pulls down hi One holds a newspaper over his head. They begin to move d steps in groups and singly now. #8 is alone. He walks int up, rain beading his face. He raises his collar, looks ar then walks off. The others begin to spread out now. Some left, some right, some going straight ahead. Camera moves up, ending with a long shot, through the pelting rain, of and the jurors spreading out silently in all directions, see each other again. And finally they are gone, and the beats down on the empty steps.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: The End
